item.description:
From the publisher's site:

Cranium Super Showdown will get your family thinking and creating in illogically logical ways!

Pick wacky challengers to take on crazy contests, like monster truck rallies and bubble-gum bubble blowing. Who would win a pie-eating contest: a monkey with backup dancers or a pirate on a pogo stick? It's up to the judge!

Have laugh-out-loud fun stating your case, flexing your logic skills, and earning trophies. With Super Showdown, everyone gets to be the judge, and Everyone Shines!

item.description: Party game where players act out words and their teammates try to guess the word. Basically it´s charades, but you may make sounds and whistle tunes as long as you don´t use actual words.

Each player tries to match the color and shape inside the egg with the ones on their cards. The first player to match all their cards to the eggs wins.

Ages 3-7.

This game is a memory-variant with pictures of the city or region the game is developed for. There are many different editions for about 200 cities or regions in Germany.

Each pair of tiles has a set of corresponding questions on it, where each tiles also gives the answer to the other one.
This way, several trivia-games can be played. Two special dice are included.

The rules describe 7 different way of plays.

Easter Island is a tiny triangular speck of land at the eastern edge of Polynesia in the middle of the Pacific Ocean. The island has fascinated travelers, mystics, and scientists for years as people have wondered how such a small, isolated area could have been home to a society that created the world's most spectacular outdoor museum. In the 1940s, Norwegian archeologist Thor Heyerdahl sailed the reed boat Kon-Tiki from South America to Easter Island to show that the technology available made it possible for Polynesia to be settled from the Americas. In the 1970s, Erich Van Daniken popularized the idea that the world was visited by ancient astronauts and the beautiful and enormous stone statutes, the Moai, of Easter Island were used as some of his "evidence."

Today, scientists around the world generally agree that Easter Island was settled from other Polynesian islands to its west, and the extreme culture that produced hundreds of stone Moai is related to other cultures in the region. The history of the island is a history of constraint, and the carving of the Moai, the rapid deforestation of the island, and the limited food sources available all worked together to build an extreme culture that became the victim of its own consumption. In this way, Easter Island today represents more than just a wonderful place to travel, but also is a reminder of the greater resource limits of our entire planet. As populations continue to grow and we put further strains on sources of fuel and food, are we heading toward the same fate that this small island suffered hundreds of years ago? The island today is owned by Chile, and the small population thrives with a few weekly flights to mainland South America and the occasional cargo ship visit.

Moai is a game that closely follows the developments and excesses of the island until the arrival of Dutch Admiral Jacob Roggeveen, the first European to discover the island and name it for the day of his discovery. Combining many of the historical features of the island's culture in an exciting and well-playing strategic game, players can have fun reliving the dramatic history of this exciting little island.

item.description: An edition of the commercially successful board game, Monopoly. This edition takes in the English town of Reading. Popular and well known landmarks are for sale including the Madejski Stadium, the Abbey Ruins and The Oracle shopping centre. Local companies and organisations logos feature prominently on the gameboard.

At first sight this "card tennis" game resembles the game Tennis ( http://boardgamegeek.com/game/2841 ) a lot. On close examination, however, there are differences which will be discussed underneath.
First of all it should be noted that the (c) from this game is 1973: two years before Tennis was released! Further, on the box it says (literal translation) "The first and only cardgame on the world based on tennis". The box furthermore states that the game was issued on occasion of the 75th year of the Dutch Tennis Association. However, a publisher cannot be found on box, or on rule sheets. Based on these data I do believe that this was the predecessor of Tennis.
Differences with Tennis: a) In this game there is no 'ball' nor a pawn (you just move the stack of played cards to the correct position). b) Cards are strictly for either backhand or forehand strokes (indicated with either B or F). c) There are more rules of which card may be played on what card (eg. smash may only following a lob).

Be the first to collect all the treasures and escape from the dungeon.

Dungeon Escape is a roll and move, dungeon crawl themed game for children ages 7 and up. Move your two children through the maze while avoiding the guards, who will send a player's piece back to the keep. Before a player's piece can exit the dungeon it must land on each of the four marked treasure spaces - Sword, Jewel, Book of Spells, and Key - and collect the corresponding treasures.

The game takes its theme from the formation of the Saxon Shieldwall in an abstract form. The pieces reflect this being resin cast representations of stylized Norman and Saxon Infantry.
 The objective of Shieldwall is to capture positions to the rear of the opponent's flanks. Offensive pieces can only attack in pairs and the defending pieces can be formed into stronger units called Shieldwalls.
 The Designer claims that the rules are easy to learn yet the depth of strategy belies its apparent simplicity.

Home Page: http://www.shieldwall.co.uk/index.html

name.value: The Game of the Wizard of Oz

item.description:
A roll and move game in which players move counters from different initial positions: Dorothy starts in Kansas, the other players in positions ahead of her (Scarecrow, Tin Man, and Lion, in that order.) The point of the game is to reach the Witch's Castle and then return to the Emerald City.

Similar in design and mechanics to the game Kentucky Derby (1938), and of typical quality of other Whitman Publishing games (paper boards, flimsy boxes, and punch-out paper pawns of other games) it looks as if Whitman didn't spend a lot on the construction of their games, apparently blowing all their budget on the purchase of the character license.

The game contains:

Linen paper game board 
1 dice
4 wooden markers
Two part box with color pictorial cover (measuring 7"x13"x1")

The featured art, though crude, is apparently inspired by the MGM Wizard Of Oz movie.

Look out...here comes the runaway clock!

Players must arrange the tiles and create a "track" for the oncoming clock before the alarm goes off and it's too late!

The clock has speed levels for players who dare to rev up the frantic fun in this family game of split second action.

A cross between a sliding 15 puzzle and a pipeline game.

name.value: Robber Barons of the Gilded Age

item.description: Some superficial similarities to Monopoly such as Board shape and pawn movement. Players build up Wealth and Economic Resources. However to win, you have to have the best Legacy, which means you must convert some of that wealth into philanthropy before the game ends. Monopolies are based on 20 different Industries including Oil, Banking, Railroads, Steel, etc. Players can own holdings within the same space. Not complex but it does offer lots of period flavor. A complete copy of the rules are available for free at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/RBGA.html

Donner Knispel is very much like Pachisi, but instead of dice rolling, movement is done by playing cards. Card have values and special abilities, what makes the game much more tactical than Pachisi.

With 4 players it is a partner game and your partner´s pieces can be moved with your own cards.

The game is set in the children's fantasy world of Donner Knispel.

Home Page: http://www.myfleat.com/

Twenty clue slides are randomly placed in the slots on the gameboard. One of the eight criminal portraits is chosen secretly and placed inside the gameboard. The portrait is now hidden by the clue slides.

Each player, in turn, spins the spinner. The spinner will tell the player which two clues may be removed from the gameboard. The player may then guess which of the eight portraits is concealed by the slides by pressing the appropriate button on the gameboard. If the word "guilty" lights up, then the player has solved the mystery and won the game.

The game uses one "D" battery and a standard flashlight's bulb.

From the Box:

A new intergenerational board game for family and friends. A game of luck, chance and strategy. Can be played in combinations of two, four or eight players. The object of the game is to fill your chosen colored areas, and to collect opponent's Jabongs.

Contains two Jagabongo boards, 64 Colored Jabongs and 3 Jates, one rule card and one bag.

Age 7+

Swedish trivia game about animals (The Fantastic World of Animals). On their turn, players choose their own task for that turn by playing a card from their hand. The categories are charade, picture quiz or one of five different categories of questions, e.g. “Animals in the air”. There are also wild cards. If the player succeeds in her task, she discards her task card. The first player to loose all her cards is the winner. When playing a charade card, the player has one minute to perform the charade. If another player makes the correct guess, then that player may discard any one card from her hand. The player performing the charade may also discard a card because the charade was a success.

8 years and up

Children´s game featuring Tummen (The Thumb), the character from the books of Inger Sandberg. Players roll the die and pick pieces from the box. Pieces have different colors on either end, e.g. yellow/blue pieces, red/green pieces. Each player is trying to make the longest row by connecting ends of the same color. If the die shows the Tummen side the player make take any piece, even from an opponent. This is where the puppets are used: The puppet is put on the player´s thumb and pointed at the piece the player wants. Longest row of pieces wins.

Contents:
49 puzzle pieces
Die w/ labels
4 thumb puppets
Rules

4 years and up

Kingdom Hearts is a Japanese trading card game based on the the video game Kingdom Hearts. In this game, you fight against the forces of evil and darkness. In order to do so, you call on allies from the worlds of Final Fantasy and Disney. With their help, you can overcome the hordes of "heartless", evil minions of darkness and despair.

Home Page: http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/kingdomhearts/

item.description: Game about the Mille's Sicilian campaign, the first campaign of Garibaldi against the Regno delle Due Sicilie. The game has 1 map, 107 counters and rules.

Travel Time is a car themed spin-and-move game given as a toy with meal by Ruby's Diners. Players move their car down a twisty road, following the instructions on the spaces. Completely random and similar to Snakes and Ladders, though thankfully shorter.

Swedish children´s game featuring the characters Pettson and his cat Findus. Players help them make a birthday cake and celebrate. They roll the die and collect chits featuring parts of the cake. If you get a chit with a muckla (the small ever present creatures from the books) you must give away a birthday present to another player. The first player to have a complete cake with candles, and who has received 2 birthday gifts, is the winner.

Contents:

Gameboard
colored die
42 small chits
48 big chits
Cloth bag
Rules

item.description:
Game released in honor of the Dutch movie Abeltje (personal name of an elevator boy). On its turn the movie was based on a children's book by a famous Dutch writer: Annie M.G. Schmidt.

The game itself is a simple roll-and-move system, where some spots have a special meaning, sometimes requiring trivia questions about the movie.

Land on an elevator to move one floor up. Reach the top floor to win the game.

Yet another very simple TdF game, with a (more-or-less) 3D-board. No date provided, but must be somewhere in the sixties (after the Dutch Jan Janssen won the Tour in '68?). Distributed by a large Dutch warehouse chain.

Use the spinner to determine the number of spots to move forward. Landing on 20 is (for some reason) mandatory to proceed.

This game was released in the Netherlands by Hema and in Germany by Multiplay.

From the back of the game:

For more than a thousand years Kama Sutra has been a guide for lovers of all ages. We have interpreted this great work and offer it to a couple as an interactive game experience.

The Kama Sutra Game™ offers lovers the opportunity to explore the sensual and sexual aspects of their body, mind, and spirit on the journey to experiencing ecstasy.

Object of the Game
- To have fun developing a deeper understanding of what you and your lover like and want in your intimate relationship.

- To engage in an extended session of lovemaking that builds on anticipation, creativity, adventure, and a progression of physical intimacy.

- To expand your sensory awareness through activities using sight, hearing, taste, smell, and... touch.

Game Play
Rolling the die and moving your game pieces, each of you will travel a different path. During the game, the two of you will be communicating, sharing, and participating in a multitude of pleasurable activities and accumulating "Sexual Position" cards. These cards will be played to complete your "journey to ecstasy."

Included in the game:
A playing board, 56 activity and position cards, a die, 2 playing pieces, and instructions.

A Journey to Ecstasy awaits you!

item.description:
Dorn is a fantasy strategic role-playing game. One of the players is the Dorn Keeper, who each turn spawns various new monsters. Five heroes need to battle the monsters, collect three sacred artifacts and finally defeat the Dorn Keeper.

The game uses no dice in combat (a hero kills a weak monster, wounds a stronger one; more than one monster is needed to wound a hero), has superb graphics and includes variety of options and skills to ensure replayability - players can choose from nine heroes, various items can be found on the board, some passages are randomly blocked, the Dorn Keeper can cast different special spells in each game, etc.)

Both heroes and the Dorn Keeper can advance in levels, thus gaining new skills (heroes by gaining experience from slain monsters, Dorn Keeper by causing enough wounds to heroes).

Home Page: http://www.dorn.cz (Czech)

item.description:
Themed on a Swedish TV-quiz for school kids, this game pits 2-4 players or teams against each other. Players answer questions and perform tricky tasks with a time limit. Score markers are moved on a track, and some spaces on the track will trigger a die roll that decides whether players score positive or negative points. This adds a considerable random element.

Contents:
Scoring track
4 pawns
4 White boards
4 pencils and erasers
330 cards
10 topic cards
10 topic markers
Die
Timer
4 puzzles
1 plastic stand

10 years and up

The name Svensson is Sweden´s equivalent to Smith, and the title means Svensson asks, Svenssons answers. In this game players earn points by answering trivia questions but also by correctly guessing how many Swedes (in %) have correctly answered the same question on www.vetgirig.nu. People have also submitted questions for the game on the website.

Contents:
Gameboard
3 decks of cards
4 pawns
1 notepad
Rules

14 years and up

Swedish trivia game about the 50´s, 60´s, 70´s, 80´s and 90´s. The main focus is on popular culture, sports etc.

Contents:
Gameboard
375 cards
25 markers
Notepad
5 pencils
5 pawns
Die
Rules

Pilare is a board game designed by the Basque game author Jorge Gómez Arrausi. It won a Proxime Accessit award in the Concurs de Creació de Jocs de Tona, 2005 ("Games Creation Contest of Tona").

Pilare is a stacking game in which pieces are moved in a way that resembles the sowing in Kalah games.

Swedish children´s game featuring spöket Laban (Little ghost Godfrey) from the books by Inger and Lasse Sandberg. The friendly ghost must practice some ghostly sounds. item.description: The Fall of Bataan is a two-player game of the American defense of the Bataan Peninsula against the Japanese in 1942. The mapsheet shows the major portion of the Bataan peninsula and the island of Corregidor. The game lasts 10 turns; at the end victory is evaluated based on the number of American units left on the map.

Container is a game about big ships and big production. Each player will play both as a producer and shipper of goods. Players will decide which products they want to produce, and which of the OTHER players' goods they want to ship out to a remote island. During these phases, players will be able to set the prices for their goods and try to maximize their cash!

Once the goods have reached the island, players will play the part of the purchaser for their tiny island. Players bid for the goods arriving each day by ship, and the highest bidder collects these goods for conversion into points at the end of the game.

Sounds simple? It is! But the real challenge is turning your home production into goods for your island. Your government is willing to subsidize your purchases, but just how much money do you want to give to your competitors for that lovely crate of goods your island desperately needs?

item.description:
Goal of this game is to become the richest and the Ribaud with most influence in the city. "Ribaud" is an ancient French word which describes a person who likes luxury and extravagance.
You lead a team of crooks which you assign missions to. Each round consists of about 10 phases:
- Draw of a Season Card
- Liberation or execution of arrested team members
- Purchase of Event cards
- Announcement of a "big coup" and negotiation between players
- Secret placement of playing pieces
- Intervention of the police
- Taking back of playing pieces
- Solution of the "big coups"
- Income of players
- Occupation of streets (and new turn)

After 8 rounds the grand winner is determined.

item.description:
From the promotional packaging inside of Zitadelle, viewable in Image 138790.

We need bread, meat, salt, fruit, dishes, and many more things for our household. We can find these wares in five stores, or we can buy them in the countryside. A new game that combines a lotto game with the ideals of a dice game.

From the promotional packaging inside of Zitadelle, viewable in Image 138790.

An interesting and varied board game. Like in the game Halma, players must get their pieces into an opposite field. However, the way to get there is over a turntable that one is allowed to turn one quarter, so long as there is another piece in the goal. That is how the fortune of the party will most change.

Game rules:

This game can be played with up to 4 players.
Each player gets 10 meeples, of which 6 are 
to be moved into the opposite destination spaces 
of the same color.

The starting player is determined by chance.
The meeples can jump over other meeples of the same 
or any other color to get to the destination 
spaces (jumping is done like in the Halma game).

Every time a player gets one of his meeples on a 
destination space, the turntable gets turned a quarter
turn to the right.

This provides for variety in the gameplay, because 
every turn changes the position of the meeples 
for every player.

The winner is the player, who is the first to get 6
meeples on the destination spaces.

The 4 remaining meeples are without importance for the
outcome of the game.


Note: This game is played without a die.

A bilingual word game that uses a game board representing various rooms in a middle school.

The goal is to be the first player to complete proper Spanish sentences in each of eight rooms.

The objectives of this board game are twofold:

1. To teach bilingual students proper Spanish sentence structure.

2. The game also introduces students to the challenges they will face upon entering middle school.

The Scarney Dice set includes 5 special Scarney dice(each d6 contains a 1,3,4,6 and "dead" on 2 opposite sides), a dice cup, chips and 80 page rule book describing more than 40 different dice games that may be played with these dice.

Some of the games include:

Scarney Put and Take Dice
Scarney Duplicate Jackpots
Scarney 21 Up and Down

Players are detectives racing to catch the thief! Detectives move around the outside of the puzzle board, the interior of the board is made up of randomly assorted tiles with pictures of diamonds, Euros and bags of loot scattered around.(or numbers, depending on which you decide to play) Normally, detectives roll and move to catch up with the thief, but when the magnifying glass is rolled, the thief moves one space and a card is turned over to reveal a sequence of 5 pictures. The timer is flipped and detectives hunt to see who can find the longest trail of pictures. Points are awarded for sequences of 3, 4 and 5, with each detective getting to move as many spaces as was the sequence he found. Game ends when a detective catches up to or passes the thief.

"History punishes those who come too late." - Mikhail Gorbachev

1989: Dawn of Freedom is an exciting, fast paced game simulating the end of the Cold War in 1989. During this amazing year, a series of democratic revolutions ended the 40 year Soviet empire in Eastern Europe. 1989 simulates the political, social and economic aspects of these revolutions using a card-driven system similar to Twilight Struggle.

"No man is so old he cannot live one more year." - Leszek Kolakowski

One player plays the Communist. At the start of the game he holds unquestioned power across the six nations of the Warsaw Pact. But there are ominous clouds on the horizon. The new leader in Moscow has declared no more will Soviet tanks prop up tottering Communist governments. The economies, after decades of central planning and stagnation, have reached various stages of crisis. Inside the churches and among the students and their professors there are dissident movements that have been emboldened. From crushing dissent to offering concessions, the Communist player will have to use a variety of strategies in a struggle to hold on to his empire.

"A bad regime is never in so great danger as when it tries to improve." - Alexis de Tocqueville

The other player plays the Democrat. At the dawn of 1989, behind the iron curtain, no one considers revolution possible. The goal of dissidents is to create a civil society outside the control of the Communist regimes. On their side are students who are fascinated with the style and pop culture of the west, and the Church. Against them is the vast apparatus of the Communist state. Their challenge is to persuade the workers, who are the bulk of society, to join their cause.

"Mr. Gorbachev, open this gate. Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!" - Ronald Reagan

item.description:
Poor Bloody Infantry 2006 is an updated version of the previous game Poor Bloody Infantry by the Rules For The Common Man team.

A miniatures game of World War 2 company level combat, PBI is designed to allow fast playing games that finish in about an hour. PBI uses a terrain map made from grid squares to address the old miniatures game problems of micro measuring and determining angles and line of sight.
Army lists are provided that span all the major countries involved and several of the minor ones over the course of the war.

PBI uses a new recon system that is substantially different than the old one, and much faster to apply. Other changes have streamlined gameplay or cleaned up rules that were somewhat confusing in the previous edition.

A Britannia-like game set in China, covering Chinese history from 400 BC to today.

From the publishers website:

"In this epic game, four players each control several countries simultaneously, with each country having their own objectives and situations, earning points for reaching various objectives, such as conquering certain provinces. The winner is the player who scores the most points at the end of the game.
This is a breathtaking game, unfolding on an illustrated map of China and over 400 separate army pieces, covering over 40 separate countries and peoples, all of the major dynasties of Chinese history, the arrival of the European powers, both World Wars and the invasion of the Japanese, right up to the present day situation, with the Communists in Mainland China and the Nationalists in Taiwan. The game occurs over 24 turns, each about 100 years long, starting from 403 BC, during the "Warring States" period as China begins to rise from its feudal age."

item.description:
Magnetic based board game from the makers of Magz magnetic construction sets.

Each player has a set of Magnetic X tiles. Each tile has different symbols on its sides (hearts, spades, clubs and diamonds). The timer is started and players race to add tiles to the board, making sure the symbols match. Tiles can be added either 2 dimension or in 3D.

Scar-Nee and i-Q Solitaire (styled that way on the board) are two distinct abstract strategy games for one to four players, marketed together and using identical equipment. Similar to Teeko but played on a 4x4 board and using 16 discs (4 different colors each numbered with pips 1 through 4).
It is likely that Scar-Nee is the same game or a direct forerunner of Scarney, and quite possible that i-Q Solitaire is also an ancestor of the solitaire versions of Scarney described in the latter's rule book.
Chess variant for 2 players (using a bigger board), 3 players (2 vs. 1) or 4 players (teams or individual)

item.description:
The object is to be the first player to unlock the Just Say No! Castle with a golden key. Players earn keys by answering a question on a card. There are no right or wrong answers. For example, "How would you say No if someone tried to give you a pill? Or "What does crack look like?" 
Game was endorsed by the National Just Say No! Foundation, a Nancy Reagan thing.

The goal of this game is to build a pyramid of monkeys. There are three types of monkeys and all three types come in three colors. Per turn you can only build your pyramid in one color. When building the other players only see the back of each monkey, so they don't know the constitution of other players' pyramids. The only way to find out is to attack! And attacking is also necessary to keep other players from finishing their pyramids. Finishing your pyramid is a true feat of bananalympics.

name.value: For Bloody Honor: The Russian Civil War
For Bloody Honor!!: Civil War Russkaya 1918-1922

item.description:
ATO (2012) edition description

Though the roots went back decades before, maybe you could say it “started” with a special train, guarded from Switzerland to a Swedish ferry… as part of the German war effort…to “plant” an exiled Vladimir Lenin back into Russian soil, fertile for revolution. The Germans hoped to take Russia out of the war, but they never dreamed how much the world would change.

Now, Against the Odds lets you explore the tangled facets of the Russian Civil War, with the historical situation exemplified by a game that handles two to four players…with up to three of them commanding the “White” Russian factions! (In multi-player games, if the Reds are defeated, the game isn’t over yet!) For Bloody Honor: Civil War Russkaya captures the interactions of political influence, railways, foreign intervention, and the discord among the White factions that gave the Bolsheviks their best chance to win in a battle against — as it seemed to them — their internal enemies and the whole Western Alliance. (Yes, there were British, French, Canadian, Australian, Indian, Japanese, and even U.S. troops fighting in Russia as late as 1920…and even later for the Japanese).

For Bloody Honor includes 10 game turns, each representing 4 months of real time from the end of 1918 to the end of 1921, and driven by chit pull which will guarantee no two turns are alike. Units represent organized troops of various sizes, with each counter (except tanks) of relatively equal strength. Yes, depending on the situations, this can become a “buckets of dice” game…or the fate of a region (and the political points that go with it) may hinge on a single unit. Defeat can be costly, not only in lost units but in the potential for defecting as your units may decide the other side has more to offer them!

Can you, as the Reds, repeat history and form a Union of Soviet Socialists Republics? Or can you, as the Whites, change the course of events in the 20th century?” The only way to find out is by playing to “Pobeda” (victory).

Bonus Game Inside! Also included in this issue is a second, bonus game, Operation Cerberus by designer Paul Rohrbaugh. This small Pocket Battle Game depicts the famous event of Feb. 1942 where heavy surface units of the German Navy dashed up the English Channel to reach home waters - right under the noses of the Royal Navy and Air Force!

Map - One full color 22"x34" mapsheet
Counters - 240 full color 1/2" die-cut pieces
Rules length - 12 pages
Charts and tables - 2 pages
Complexity - Medium
Solitaire suitability - Average

Design - Mark Woloshen
Development - Lembit Tohver
Graphics - Mark Mahaffey

Against the Odds Magazine #37.

				
					Firefight (2006) edition description

Mark Woloshen's epic game covering the Russian Civil War has been teaching history students the nuances of this complicated period. Now, Firefight Games offers it as a wargame. The game is unique for the rules cover everything in simplicity yet, making the correct decision makes it tough to master! Political influence and recruiting plays a vital and realistic role, for these decisions will impact military units and their use! Technology (tanks, aircraft) is important but it alone cannot win the game. The beautiful area map conveys at a glance the massive expanses of the war, for each area plays a critical political role. The game is deceptively simple to learn, yet, like Chess, hard to master. A grand strategic game on the Russian Civil War from 1918 to 1922, with each turn being four months, units represent 5 - 15,000 men, while tanks, aircraft, armor cars and armor trains are abstracted amounts. One player plays the Red , the other plays the White Factions (Polish, Kolchak, Denikin etc). The map is divided into zones. The game, designed by Mark Woloshen, designed a game that is used frequently by his students to learn about the complexities of the RCW. Thus, it is focused on how the political influence and control impacted the military events. One cannot win by military means alone. The game relies on activations and recruiting new men to man the armies is of major importance subject the game's political realities! Unlike other strategic RCW games, this plays in a few hours' time.

Designed and published by the sailboarding community in 1988, Pro-Am pits players (sailboarders) against each other as they race around the board collecting sponsorships, forging a career, and testing their knowledge on sailboarding. The game can be played on three different levels, from the experienced sail boarder down to the first timers and non-sailboarders who play on the 'Learner' level. Nicely outfitted with plenty of sponsorship options, career directions, and 'sailboards' pieces, the game delves deep into the world of sailboard racing.

Simple spin-and-move game distinguished only by presentation. The pawns are lead figures designed to resemble television cameras. The backdrop to the gameboard has pop-up figures giving the gameboard a 3-D effect. The game comes with a xylophone that must be played or the participant who misses the cue is penalized. The first to reach the finish space is the winner.

An unusual place on the GameBoard is the Station Break Area which is represented by clock symbols. If you land on or pass over one of these Station Breaks you must ring the TIME SIGNAL TONES to properly identify the network. If you fail to do so you must move your camera back 15 spaces.

Each player will act as quizmaster for another player so everyone can compete. A random category for each round is determined by the Bid Wheel. Every correct answer earns the player fifty dollars. A round consists of four questions for each player. The winner of round chooses a card which represents a treasure chest and its treasure. The player also spins the Bid Wheel. The player may now choose between the known amount on the Bid Wheel (range: $250 to $2000) or take whatever happens to be on the card (range: $0 to $25,000)

The player who chooses and keeps the $25,000 treasure chest card is the immediate winner. Otherwise, the game goes the full four rounds. The winner is the person who has the most money after four rounds of play.

The game is based on a popular television series of the fifties.

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
The players take on the role of television show producer vying to book the best guests for television’s “The Today Show”. The deck is divided into four suits. Each suit represents a category of guest. Each suit has cards valued one through twelve; one being the greatest value and twelve having the least value. There are also four wild cards, valued at thirteen, to bring the total number of cards in the deck to fifty-two.

All players place their pawns on the start space. Each player chooses a card secretly. All players reveal their chosen cards simultaneously. The player who played the highest valued card gets to advance one’s own pawn the number of spaces equal to value of the winning card. The rules are do not state what happens if two or more players tie. If two or more players play wild cards, there is no winner and the hand is replayed.

Certain spaces on the track assign a player who happens to land on them a personal trump suit. This trump stays in effect until the player moves on.

The hand is over when someone lands on the “Off the Air” space at the end of the track. The value of the cards remaining in the hand of the players is totaled and added to the score of the player who ended the round. All players receive the value of the cards in tricks each has taken. The first player to score five hundred points is the winner.

From the back of the rule book:

FUTURE TANK

Future tank is a two-player board game pitting players against each other with tank armies of their own choosing!

Players have four different types of tanks to choose from in which to build their armies:

1) Fast-Assault Tanks: Quick, highly maneuverable and able to outflank any other tank with cutting precision.

2) Light-Assault Tanks: Fast, but more heavily armored and more heavily weaponed. It can pack a solid punch.

3) Heavy-Assault Tanks: Slow, but carry the biggest gun!

4) Missile Tanks: Slow and heavily armored. Able to kill from a distance.

Rules are easy-to-read and play-action can let you start blasting away in the first turn! Terrain features are optional and six scenarios are included.

Average Play Time: 20-40 Minutes."

Played on a chess board, this games uses either the photocopied "counters" from the book, or minis of your choosing. You will also need a D4, D6, D8 and D12. A basic move and attack format. Lighter moves further and heaver shoots further. Each tank has a diagram showing its armor amounts (think SFB shields) and has ratings for movement, firing ranges and weapon damage.
UnStack was created by Professor João Pedro Neto, Lisbon (Portugal), in 2001. It is a stacking game in which counters are distributed in a way that resembles the "sowing" in Kalah games.

item.description:
THE $64,000 QUESTION is a board game based on the UK version of the TV Game Show. The aim of the game is to work along a question path answering questions and enter 'the isolator' to answer the $64,000 question. The first player to get the $64,000 question correct is the winner.

Questions are categorized into 10 subject areas which are selected by the roll of a 10 sided die. An additional category is provided when playing with younger players.

From the box:

"POETIC JUSTICE" is the super-duper, pretty-witty game where one word leads to another. All you need is a dash of logic and a flash of inspiration to uncover the poetic solutions.

Poetic Cards consist of cleverly worked clues which are solved with rhyming couplets and a splash of humor!

Depending on where you land on the board you may have to play solo, challenge another player or join everyone else in this game of reason and rhyme."

NOEL'S HOUSE PARTY is a board game spin-off from the UK's TV Show of the same name. It involves recreations of the main features of the show.

From the box:

"Round and around Crinkley Bottom you go... in for the Music Game .... down the cellar for 'Wait till I get you home'. But who's that at the door? - better go and find out, oh no! you've landed in the grunge tank - or worse still you've to face the NTV talent test.

This new and exiting family game is fast-paced and action packed and features a fully working three-dimensional 'Grad a Grand' booth complete with miniature money".

The aim of the game is to collect the most money by moving around the board and performing a variety of actions based on the draw of a card:

NTV - act out the instructions on the card.
KNOCK KNOCK - Guess the identity of someone from clues on the card.
WAIT TILL I GET YOU HOME! - Guessing what answer another player will give to a question.
MUSIC GAME - Music based trivia or performance card.

Other spaces require you to spin again, miss a turn or take possion of the Gotcha! (allowing you to score double points whilst you have it).

Purple Ronnie's Groovy Game of RISKS AND RHYMES is an adult game involving moving around a board, making up poems, acting and drinking (preferably alcoholic beverages)

There are two decks of cards:
the first represents different character types (i.e.slob, sex goddess, mummy's boy ...)
the second comprises risks and rhymes. Risk cards involve acting out whatever is written on the card. The rhyme cards contain a short poem to which the final line needs to be added.

Players move round the board as per the roll of a die. The space they land on determines what action they need to perform:
- Borrow a character card from another player
- Miss a turn
- take a Risk and Rhymes card for themselves or another player
- Roll again
- Give a character card to another player

All risks and rhymes must be performed in the style of the character card in play at the time with a successful performance resulting in winning of that character card. The winner is the player who, at the end of the game, has collected the most character cards.

The players must deduce which of the six given historical figures is the correct one. The players choose and ask the questions on the cards given to them while the quizmaster responds according to the answer key. The player who gives the correct answer scores points depending on how many questions were asked by the players. The first to score one hundred points is the winner.

The game is loosely based on a television series designed by Monty Hall of Let’s Make a Deal fame. Mr. Hall’s name is misspelled on the box lid.

Word game similar to Diamino, by the same publisher, except that it uses hexagonal tiles instead of square ones. Unlike Diamino, tiles do not have point values
Like Diamino, it has some tiles with a red logo or design on it.

Four "snakes" consisting of 12 tokens each try to conquer numbered spaces on the game board. A dice rolling game for up to four players. 
Roll the dice and move your snake by placing same number of pieces as rolled from the end of your snake in front of it. Try to surround a circle with your snake and score by placing a snake piece inside the surrounded circle. So your snake becomes shorter and you will have less pieces to surround the next circles.
A fishing game with semi-precious stones. Players hide magnetic stones in 12 heaps of non-magnetic stones, then try to fish out as many magnetic stones from all heaps as they can.

subtitle - A wargamers' guide to the Western Desert Campaign 1940-1942

Book including miniatures rules for wargames in the North African desert during WW2.

From the publisher's description;

...contents include a summary of the actual campaign, illustrated with numerous maps, plus technical specifications for the vehicles, tanks, guns and aircraft used. Further chapters cover terrain, communications, visibility, navigation, firing tank and anti-tank guns, 'brewing up', air operations, the Long Range Desert Group, minefields and supply. There are also appendices on British and Axis armored formations, recognition silhouettes, armor penetration tables and the construction of various wargaming aids.

Small paperback book serving as an introduction to miniatures wargaming and also containing rules for use from the ancient period up to the American Civil War (1 rule set for the whole lot !)

Rules are based on rolling a one die for each group of six figures when shooting, or counting heads and multiplying by a die roll in melee. Also includes rules for differing formations and for morale.

name.value: Joseph And His Coat Of Many Colors

item.description:
Joseph And His Coat Of Many Colors is a variation on the popular game of UNO with uniquely illustrated cards depicting the biblical character of Joseph wearing his colored coats. Players are trying to empty their hands of cards by playing them to a common pile, matching cards by color, number, or action. The deck is made up of 4 sets of differently colored cards with numbers from 1 to 6. There are also Miracle cards (wild cards), cards that cause the next player to pick up 1 or 2 cards, and Skip cards.

Note: This game is different from UNO in the following ways:
- Instead of "Draw 4 wild cards", this game contains some "Draw 1" cards. This is in addition to the "Draw 2 cards" both games have.
- This game has only a 35-card deck.
- When a person has only one card left in their hand, they are to call out "Joseph".

An 18XX game series based on the railroad development in Malaya (Malaysia before Independence). It is set in 1885, when the first railroads were built to transport cargo between the Ports.

Special rules include:

a) The map includes part of Southern Siam (Thailand).
b) A Siam Pass is up for auction after the Private Companies Auction but before the Stock buying round (on the first turn). Siam Pass is then auctioned out again when the first '3' train and '5' train is bought. The holder of the Siam Pass allow one of his/her Corporation to run trains into Siam without rolling the 'Train Hijack' die. (See Below) 
c) Train Hijack mechanics. Where, while running trains into Siam, the corporation president must roll a die. On the roll of 4,5 or 6, the train is hijacked and no revenues are generated from that train. The train card is then flipped over and cannot be used until after the next stock round.

Based on the Anima: Beyond Fantasy roleplaying game setting, Anima: Tactics is a skirmish-level miniatures combat game that pits heroic characters against each other in the struggle between Light and Dark. The system uses 10-sided dice as well as character statcards and asset cards that provide new abilities for the characters.

Each player brings a party of heroes to the field of battle, choosing characters, equipment, and other advantages with total levels no more than the fixed value selected for the game (250 levels for a standard game). No party may contain characters from both the Light and Darkness faction, unless all characters in the party are drawn from the same affiliation (there are eight affiliations in the game, such as the Church, the Empire, or the Black Sun trading cartel).

In the standard 250 LV game, each player will have 4 ~ 6 models. The winner is the player with the most levels of characters still on the battlefield at the end of ten turns.

There are two starter sets available right now - Light faction and Dark faction:
Each starter set includes
2 unpainted pewter figures (around 100 LV)
2 advantage cards
1 rulebook
1 ten-sided die
Several action counters and state counters.

Anima Tactics: Black Sun Box Set

Anima Tactics: Valis Ul Del Vilfain

name.value: High School Musical Jeu avec DVD

item.description:
From bestbuy.com summary:

"High school is a stage and here's your chance to be a part of the show. Jump into the hit Disney Channel movie High School Musical with this fun, interactive DVD game. Enjoy video clips, original outtakes and all of the songs and dances you love from the movie.

Compete against your friends in four challenging categories: Outtakes, Song, Dance and Relationship. The first player to make his or her way around the school for the final call back audition is the winner. Prove you have what it takes to make it in high school. After all, it really is just a song and a dance. "

DISASTER! is for ages 8 and up, 2 to 4 players with an average playing time 15 - 30 minutes.
Learn about natural disasters and how they affect the U.S, including how scientists rank the strengths of the different disasters. Learn which geographic areas are at risk and how the seasons affect a disaster's occurrence. Tornadoes, earthquakes, hurricanes, floods, wildfires... are just a few of the disasters that you'll face in this game. Game includes: Deck of 59 full color board Disaster & Defense playing cards, full-color game board featuring map of US, 15 color territory marker pieces.

Each card contains facts and information about specific historical disasters. In DISASTER!, you want to control territories of the US that are worth different points. You gain territories by playing disaster cards against your opponent's territories, like a hurricane against Florida. But your opponent might have a defense... like The National Hurricane Center... To block you. Each game last 16 turns, with each turn a different season. Many disasters can only be played during certain seasons. At end of the last turn , add up your points for the territories you control, the player with the highest points wins!

name.value: Confucianism and the Succession Crisis of the Wanli Emperor, 1587

item.description:
From Description:

Confucianism and the Succession Crisis of the Wanli Emperor, 1587 seeks to introduce undergraduate students to the suppleness and power of Confucian thought as applied to issues of governance during the Ming dynasty. The game is set in the Hanlin Academy. Most students are members of the Grand Secretariat of the Hanlin Academy, the body of top-ranking graduates of the civil service examination who serve as advisers to the Wanli emperor. Some Grand Secretaries are Confucian "purists,” who hold that tradition obliges the emperor to name his first-born son as successor; others, in support of the most senior of the Grand Secretaries, maintain that it is within the emperor’s right to choose his successor; and still others, as they decide this matter among many issues confronting the empire, continue to scrutinize the teachings of Confucianism for guidance. The game unfolds amidst the secrecy and intrigue within the walls of the Forbidden City, as scholars struggle to apply Confucian precepts to a dynasty in peril.

name.value: Meatgrinder Battle of Xuan Loc April 1975

item.description:
This is a redux to Perry Moore's original game. Defiance: The Battle of Xuan Loc (Swedish Games).

Covers the Battle of Xuan Loc April 1975. Basically ARVN defenders backed up by air power vs. hordes of NVA with tanks and heavy artillery. This was the last stand of the South Vietnamese Army against all odds (which is why it may become an ATO issue game). The ARVN 18th division armed with M-48 Tanks and Cluster bombs conduct themselves in a heroic manner, so much so, that it becomes noticed by the outside world media press. The battle involved large amounts of aircraft and tanks. The ARVN defiant stand stunned the three NVA Divisions assigned to take the town. The two sides clashed for 10 days-it became a battle of honor! This game is a much improved version of Perry's earlier 1982 game.

System is similar to Perry Moore's Nanawa: Verdun in the Chaco War, July 1933.

name.value: No. 20 of 36 Chinese Strategy of War

item.description:
In Wolf in Disguise, players seek to wreak havoc at the peaceful ranch. Each player is a Shepherd who tries to gain the most profit on the ranch. Player can hire wolf to attack other player's sheep or raise shepherd dog to protect his own sheep. However, to make the game interesting, all the wolves are disguised as sheep.

Wolf in disguise is a game derived from the famous book, The Art of War - Thirty-Six Stratagems thought by some to be written by Sun Tzu. The idea came from the twentieth Stratagem in the book, "Fish in troubled water."

name.value: Legends of the Ancient World: The Gates to the Underworld

item.description:
From the publisher:

"Only the Necromancer can help you summon back the demons of the underworld that have risen to plague the land. But you must first seal the breaches through which the demons entered the world of the living before undertaking the journey to Hell itself. "

This is a paragraph-system game with a hex board and counters, inspired by Metagaming's Melee.

Children´s trivia game about Pippi Longstocking and friends.

Each player receives eight tiles with pictures from the books. Players lay them on the table in front of them and memorize the order of the pictures. Then they turn their tiles face-down. Players are then ready to take turns rolling the die and moving on the board.

If they land on a red spot, the game master picks up a red card and reads a quote from a story. The text is associated with one of the pictures on the players´ tiles. The first player to turn up the right tile gets a freckle painted in her face - a make-up stick is included in the game! As you know, Pippi is proud of her freckles.

If they land on a yellow spot, they get one freckle.

If they land on a green spot, the player answers a question from a card. If correct, the player gets one gold coin.

The first player to land on one of the blue spots gets the coin that was placed their before game start. No new coins are added during the game.

The first player to reach the finish gets three coins. The winner is the player with most points (total of freckles and coins!).

Age 5 years and up. Children will need someone to read the cards.

name.value: The Threshold of Democracy: Athens in 403 B.C.

item.description:
The Threshold of Democracy: Athens in 403 B.C. is one of the first games in the Reacting to the Past game series originally created by Mark Carnes, history professor at Barnard College/Columbia University. These games are intended for undergraduate or graduate students led by an instructor (facilitator)

Participants are assigned roles with secret role sheets and secret victory objectives. The object of the game is to achieve the stated objective for each player.

The game is set in Athens soon after the tyrants installed by Sparta were overthrown. The game focuses upon the future of democracy in Athens. Participants are given a variety of roles: moderate democrats, radical democrats, oligarchs, Socratics and more.

Participants need read and refer to Plato's Republic (not included) and excerpts (included) from Thucydides, Xenophon, and other primary sources.

The game requires substantial reading, writing, and verbal debate.

Awards:
The Reacting to the Past series won the 2004 Hesburgh Award for innovative undergraduate education using gaming.

The American Historical Association awarded the 2006 William Gilbert Award to Mark C. Carnes for the best article on teaching history--focusing upon the Reacting to the Past games.

name.value: Scene it? Gute Zeiten Schlechte Zeiten

item.description:
In this version of "Scene It? Movie?" you find scenes and questions about the German daily soap "Gute Zeiten Schlechte Zeiten".] It is a stand alone DVD game about famous german TV show.

"How much do you know about Gute Zeiten Schlechte Zeiten (as seen on TV)? Test your knowledge of the entire Gute Zeiten Schlechte Zeiten gang with Scene It? The Gute Zeiten Schlechte Zeiten Game Pack. Featuring clips, puzzlers and questions from all seasons! Scene It? The Gute Zeiten Schlechte Zeiten Game Pack can add to any Scene It? game or play as a stand-alone title. For 2 or more adult players."

Each Anno Domini set consists of 336 cards, with a description of a historical event on one side of the card, and the year (and sometimes specific date) in which it happened on the other.

Each player receives nine of these cards (or less, if you want the game to be shorter), and may only look at the descriptions. Players then put in turn a card on the table, *trying* to put theirs in chronological order. A player may, instead of adding a card, claim that the order in which the cards were put is incorrect. In this case all cards are turned over and the correct years revealed.
If the order was correct then the doubting player receives two cards and skips a turn. If the order was incorrect then the previous player, who accepted the order as correct, receives three cards. The first player that gets rid of all the cards wins.

Bluffing is as least as important as knowledge in this game. Most events are rather obscure or are hard to date exactly, so this ain’t no game for the nerds/geeks of this world, even they might think so, because it’s full of surprises and pure fun. Highly recommended, because Anno Domini is a blast to play, is a very enjoyable social event and you even learn something from it.

Unfortunately there is no English edition in existence, but this game could be a good way, to improve your already existing German skills or a very good reason, to learn German language in the first place.

The set "Österreich" contains historical events which are related to Austria. This relationship is not necessary obvious. Like all Anno Domini the Austria edition can be played as standalone or mixed with some or even all editions.

Part of the Anno Domini series

Game description from the publisher:

Veritas is a Euro-style board game about the preservation of truth in Dark Ages France. Each player represents some "truth" that's trying to be preserved for posterity by diligent book-copying monks. Players place and copy book tokens in monasteries, then pick up stacks of books and spread them around France. Each turn, a monastery will burn down, and the books in it may be destroyed. After the monasteries have burned down, players can move through them, so travel on the board gets faster as the game progresses. When scoring chips are drawn, each player whose ideology dominates a region scores points. The first player to score 100 points wins, becoming the dominant truth as the Dark Ages end.

item.description: This is a special Version for the 250th birthday of the Austrian lottery.

Directly from the rules:

By offering cards for completion the players jointly create a path that takes them through various periods taken from the life of Vincent Van Gogh.
The first player to get rid of all his cards is the winner.

Contents of the box:

 48 cards
 4 brushes
 4 holders
 1 dice
 rule book

name.value: Rousseau, Burke, and Revolution in France, 1791

item.description:
From Description:

Rousseau, Burke, and Revolution in France, 1791 plunges students into the intellectual, political, and ideological currents that surged through revolutionary Paris in the summer of 1791. Students are leaders of major factions within the National Assembly (and in the streets outside) as it struggles to create a constitution amidst internal chaos and threats of foreign invasion. Will the king retain power? Will the priests of the Catholic Church obey the “general will” of the National Assembly or the dictates of the pope in Rome? Do traditional institutions and values constitute restraints on freedom and individual dignity or are they its essential bulwarks?


Are slaves, women, and Jews entitled to the “rights of man”? Is violence a legitimate means of changing society or of purging it of dangerous enemies? In wrestling with these issues, students consult Jean-Jacques Rousseau’s Social Contract and Edmund Burke’s Reflections on the Revolution in France, among other texts.

1881 is an 18xx game about the tram companies of Berlin and the arrival in the city of the S-Bahn. It was designed by Michael Mette and published by him under license from Hartland Trefoil. It was later released in a free downloadable version.

item.description:
This is an early tile-placement game. The equipment consists of 80 hexagonal wooden tiles - 10 house tiles for each player, 1 town hall tile, and 39 road tiles of various configurations.

Players play a road tile of their choice each turn in an effort to create empty spaces with exactly three neighbors, in which they can place their houses. The object is place all of one's house tiles and then the town hall tile.

A slightly altered version was published (probably in the 1960s) by Whitman, with cardboard tiles.

From the publisher's website:

World War 2 air combat game depicting the nighttime air raids of British bombers hitting German cities.

As the head of the British Bomber Command, you plan the attacks on Germany in order to undermine the morale of the civilian population. Or as a General of the German Air Force (Luftwaffe), you defend using your ace squadrons and organizing an effective civil defense.

The gameboard enables you to set up countless variations of these historic events. You play as many nights as you wish - each night takes 30-45 minutes to resolve.

Immerse yourself in the strategic and tactical thinking needed to survive in those dark times.

Gameplay allows for easy entry into the action with some advanced rules for the hearty wargamer. The game rules include weather conditions, full moon/new moon bonuses and penalties, clouds and thunderclouds, fog, flak, searchlights, balloon barriers, target markers, and much more.

The British player secretly plots the course of the bomber while the Mosquito acts as escort or decoy. The German player tries to figure out where the bomber is going, making sure to efficiently use the fuel to get as many hits on the bomber as possible.

item.description:
From the Website:
This brand new game from veteran homeschoolers Greg & Pamela Berthume combines all of the fun and educational qualities of the old-fashioned family favorite board game and celebrates the best of homeschooling. You start out at Home Sweet Homeschool and pass by squares like Public School Tax or Field Trip, and if you land on the right square you might get to purchase a Big Family Bus or a Cool As Can Be SUV! And of course, you'll want to try to avoid running into the Truancy Officer lying in wait to send a homeschooler to court! Don't worry, you can use your "HSLDA Member - GET OUT OF COURT FREE" card.

While playing you'll get to buy properties with your favorite homeschool companies and organizations like HSLDA, Rosetta Stone, Sonlight Curriculum, Greek 'n' Stuff, KONOS, Schoolhouse Store, WriteShop, Artes Latinae, Excellence in Writing, Geography Matters, CLASS, Christian Liberty Press, Centrifuge Language Arts, Systematic Mathematics, Cornerstone Curriculum, Rainbow Resources, Homeschooling Parent Magazine, Teach Magazine, World Magazine, God's World News, The Young Scientist Club, Learning Adventures, HomeschoolersConnecting.com and Creation Illustrated.

Home Page : http://homeschoolopoly.com/

Roll-and-move game for children. Each player represents a kangaroo racing to arrive first at the finish line. Along the route, the players can pick up special cards that are needed to overcome certain obstacle squares.

To win, you need to visit eight places (10 points each) and have the fewest demerits (-5 each). Players begin and end at home and move on all rolls except doubles. Doubles change the traffic light spaces in the city portion of the board from red to green (or vice versa). Players cannot move through red lights. If a player lands on a red space (not red light), he is in violation and has to roll to see if he will get a demerit or not. If a player lands on the same space as another player he causes an accident. Five demerits result in having the license revoked.

A board game for children (4+ years).

In their turn, a player picks a card showing an animal. Then they have to find it by touch only from an opaque bag. If they find it before time runs out, they can advance.

A balancing game for children (3+ years). Players stack the cardboard animals into different kinds of towers trying to keep them from falling.

The game comes with 12 pieces: 1 aunt, 4 cats, and 7 smaller presents.

item.description: A racing game for children (3+ years). 6 different cardboard animals and riders are included in the box. They are folded in the middle and a string passed through them and tied to a chair or table. Players then jolt the string up and down so that their animal moves and try to reach the goal first.
A waterproof memory game for children (4+ years) to play in the tub. Find the pairs from all the fish floating in the water.
A simple roll and move game for children (5+ years). This game is based on Snakes and Ladders, but with players controlling penguins in the Arctic instead.
A simple balancing game for children (5+ years). Players set the wooden bugs on to a big flower that stands on a small base and try to keep it from falling. The game comes with 29 wooden pieces.
A card game for children (7+ years). This is a Space themed poker game. Players try to get space shuttles or planets, or better still, whole intergalactic sets, in order to win.
A card game for children (9+ years). Players have to guess who the Mystery Star is by asking the right questions and paying attention to the questions the others make.

A card game for children (6+ years).

From the publisher: "Game of observation and speed. Pick up an apple, swat a mosquito, place a bee on its flower ? No time to think about ! But for sure, you have to be the first one to do it."

A mosquito, a flower and an apple are placed in front of all the players and each of the players gets his/her own bee. All the cards, showing either a mosquito, a bee or an apple, are dealt to the players. During the game, all the players turn over one of their cards simultaneously. If there are two (or more) of the same cards shown in the newly turned over cards, then the player s to whom the cards belong must get into action:

- If there are 2 or more mosquito cards, they have to squat the mosquito
- If there are 2 or more apple cards, they have to grab the apple
- If there are 2 or more bee cards, they have to take their own bee and put it on the flower

The fastest player wins a ladybird chip. Making an incorrect move, ie squatting the flower or grabbing the mosquito, costs a ladybird chip.

The player with the most ladybird chips when all the cards have been turned over wins the game.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
A card game for children (8+ years).

From the publisher: "An incredibly funny girl's game to liven up pyjama parties. Tears of laughters, secrets, revelations : unforgettable moments to share with friends and to write in a secret book."
